description:
Arcicella rosea is a species of bacterium that belongs to the phylum Bacteroidetes. It is a Gram-negative, aerobic, and non-spore-forming bacterium. Arcicella rosea cells are typically rod-shaped and exhibit a characteristic pink or reddish pigmentation, which is due to the presence of carotenoid pigments.

This species was first isolated from a freshwater environment and is known to be found in various aquatic habitats, such as lakes, rivers, and wetlands. Arcicella rosea is considered a chemoorganotrophic bacterium, meaning it derives its energy and carbon from organic compounds in its environment.

The optimal growth conditions for Arcicella rosea include moderate temperatures (around 25-30Â°C) and slightly acidic to neutral pH levels. This bacterium is capable of utilizing a range of carbohydrates and other organic compounds as carbon and energy sources.

While the ecological role of Arcicella rosea in its natural environments is not fully understood, it is believed to be involved in the cycling of organic matter and nutrient dynamics in aquatic ecosystems. Further research is needed to elucidate the specific functional and metabolic capabilities of this bacterium and its interactions within the microbial communities it inhabits.
